# History of ballet

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Main articles: [Ballet](/wiki/Ballet "Ballet") and [History of
dance](/wiki/History_of_dance "History of dance")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Sleeping_beauty_cast.jpg/300px-
Sleeping_beauty_cast.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sleeping_beauty_cast.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sleeping_beauty_cast.jpg "Enlarge")

A publicity photo for the premiere of Tchaikovsky's ballet [The Sleeping
Beauty](/wiki/The_Sleeping_Beauty_\(ballet\) "The Sleeping Beauty \(ballet\)")
(1890).

**Ballet** is a formalized form of dance with its origins in the [Italian
Renaissance](/wiki/Italian_Renaissance "Italian Renaissance") courts of the
15th and 16th centuries. Ballet spread from [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy") to
[France](/wiki/France "France") with the help of [Catherine de'
Medici](/wiki/Catherine_de%27_Medici "Catherine de' Medici"), where ballet
developed even further under her aristocratic influence. An early example of
Catherine's development of ballet is through 'Le Paradis d' Amour', a piece of
work presented at her daughter's wedding, [Marguerite de
Valois](/wiki/Margaret_of_Valois "Margaret of Valois") to [Henry of
Navarre](/wiki/Henry_of_Navarre "Henry of Navarre"). Aristocratic money was
responsible for the initial stages of development in 'court ballet', as it was
royal money that dictated the ideas, literature and music used in ballets that
were created to primarily entertain the aristocrats of the time. The first
formal 'court ballet' ever recognized was staged in 1573, 'Ballet des
Polonais'. In true form of royal entertainment, 'Ballet des Polonais' was
commissioned by Catherine de' Medici to honor the [Polish](/wiki/Poland
"Poland") ambassadors who were visiting [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") upon the
accession of [Henry of Anjou](/wiki/Henry_III_of_France "Henry III of France")
to the throne of Poland. In 1581, Catherine de' Medici commissioned another
court ballet, _[Ballet Comique de la Reine](/wiki/Ballet_Comique_de_la_Reine
"Ballet Comique de la Reine")_ , however it was her compatriot, [Balthasar de
Beaujoyeulx](/wiki/Balthasar_de_Beaujoyeulx "Balthasar de Beaujoyeulx"), who
organized the ballet. Catherine de' Medici and Balthasar de Beaujoyeulx were
responsible for presenting the first court ballet ever to apply the principles
of Baif's Academie, by integrating poetry, dance, music and set design to
convey a unified dramatic storyline. Moreover, the early organization and
development of 'court ballet' was funded by, influenced by and produced by the
aristocrats of the time, fulfilling both their personal entertainment and
political propaganda needs.

In the late 17th century [Louis XIV](/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France "Louis XIV of
France") founded the Académie Royale de Musique (the [Paris
Opera](/wiki/Paris_Opera "Paris Opera")) within which emerged the first
professional theatrical [ballet company](/wiki/Ballet_company "Ballet
company"), the [Paris Opera Ballet](/wiki/Paris_Opera_Ballet "Paris Opera
Ballet"). The predominance of French in the [vocabulary of
ballet](/wiki/Glossary_of_ballet "Glossary of ballet") reflects this history.
Theatrical ballet soon became an independent form of art, although still
frequently maintaining a close association with opera, and spread from the
heart of Europe to other nations. The [Royal Danish
Ballet](/wiki/Royal_Danish_Ballet "Royal Danish Ballet") and the [Imperial
Ballet](/wiki/Mariinsky_Ballet "Mariinsky Ballet") of the [Russian
Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") were founded in the 1740s and
began to flourish, especially after about 1850. In 1907 the Russian ballet in
turn moved back to France, where the [Ballets Russes](/wiki/Ballets_Russes
"Ballets Russes") of [Sergei Diaghilev](/wiki/Sergei_Diaghilev "Sergei
Diaghilev") and its successors were particularly influential. Soon ballet
spread around the world with the formation of new companies, including
London's [The Royal Ballet](/wiki/The_Royal_Ballet "The Royal Ballet") (1931),
the [San Francisco Ballet](/wiki/San_Francisco_Ballet "San Francisco Ballet")
(1933), [American Ballet Theatre](/wiki/American_Ballet_Theatre "American
Ballet Theatre") (1937), The Royal Winnipeg Ballet (1939), [The Australian
Ballet](/wiki/The_Australian_Ballet "The Australian Ballet") (1940), the [New
York City Ballet](/wiki/New_York_City_Ballet "New York City Ballet") (1948),
the [National Ballet of Canada](/wiki/National_Ballet_of_Canada "National
Ballet of Canada") (1951), and the [National Ballet Academy and Trust of
India](/wiki/National_Ballet_Academy_and_Trust_of_India "National Ballet
Academy and Trust of India") (2002).[1]

In the 20th century styles of ballet continued to develop and strongly
influence broader [concert dance](/wiki/Concert_dance "Concert dance"), for
example, in the United States choreographer [George
Balanchine](/wiki/George_Balanchine "George Balanchine") developed what is now
known as [neoclassical ballet](/wiki/Neoclassical_ballet "Neoclassical
ballet"), subsequent developments have included [contemporary
ballet](/wiki/Contemporary_ballet "Contemporary ballet") and [post-
structural](/wiki/Post-structuralism "Post-structuralism") ballet, for example
seen in the work of [William Forsythe](/wiki/William_Forsythe_\(dancer\)
"William Forsythe \(dancer\)") in Germany.

The [etymology](/wiki/Etymology "Etymology") of the word "ballet" reflects its
history. The word _ballet_ comes from French and was borrowed into English
around the 17th century. The French word in turn has its origins in Italian
_balletto_ , a [diminutive](/wiki/Diminutive "Diminutive") of _ballo_ (dance).
_Ballet_ ultimately traces back to [Italian](/wiki/Italian_language "Italian
language") _ballare_ , meaning _" to dance"_.[2]

## Origins[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Origins")]

### Renaissance – Italy and
France[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Renaissance – Italy and France")]

Main article: [Renaissance dance](/wiki/Renaissance_dance "Renaissance dance")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Ballet_1582.png/180px-
Ballet_1582.png)](/wiki/File:Ballet_1582.png)

[](/wiki/File:Ballet_1582.png "Enlarge")

Engraving of the second scene of the _[Ballet Comique de la
Reine](/wiki/Ballet_Comique_de_la_Reine "Ballet Comique de la Reine")_ ,
staged in Paris in 1581 for the French court.

Ballet originated in the [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance")
[court](/wiki/Royal_court "Royal court") as an outgrowth of court pageantry in
[Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy"),[3] where aristocratic weddings were lavish
celebrations. [Tutus](/wiki/Tutu_\(ballet\) "Tutu \(ballet\)"), ballet
slippers and pointe work were not yet used. The choreography was adapted from
court dance steps.[4] Performers dressed in fashions of the times. For women
that meant formal gowns that covered their legs to the ankle.[5] Early ballet
was participatory, with the audience joining the dance towards the end.

[Domenico da Piacenza](/wiki/Domenico_da_Piacenza "Domenico da Piacenza") (c.
1400–c. 1470) was one of the first dancing masters. Along with his students,
[Antonio Cornazzano](/wiki/Antonio_Cornazzano "Antonio Cornazzano") and
[Guglielmo Ebreo](/wiki/Guglielmo_Ebreo "Guglielmo Ebreo"), he was trained in
dance and responsible for teaching nobles the art. Da Piacenza left one work:
_De arte saltandi et choreus ducendi_ (On the art of dancing and conducting
dances), which was put together by his students.[6]

In 1489 [Galeazzo, Duke of Milan](/wiki/Gian_Galeazzo_Sforza "Gian Galeazzo
Sforza"), married [Isabella of
Aragon](/wiki/Isabella_of_Aragon,_Duchess_of_Milan "Isabella of Aragon,
Duchess of Milan") in [Tortona](/wiki/Tortona "Tortona"). An elaborate dance
entertainment was arranged for the celebrations by the Italian dance master
Bergonzio di Botta. The dances were linked by a slim narrative concerning
[Jason](/wiki/Jason "Jason") and the [Argonauts](/wiki/Argonauts "Argonauts"),
and each corresponded to a different course for the dinner. Tristano Calco of
Milan wrote about the event, and it was considered so impressive, that many
similar spectacles were organized elsewhere.[7][8]

Ballet was further shaped by the French _[ballet de cour](/wiki/Ballet_de_cour
"Ballet de cour")_ , which consisted of social dances performed by the
nobility in tandem with music, speech, verse, song, pageant, decor and
costume.[9] When [Catherine de' Medici](/wiki/Catherine_de%27_Medici
"Catherine de' Medici"), an Italian aristocrat with an interest in the arts,
married the French crown heir [Henry II](/wiki/Henry_II_of_France "Henry II of
France"), she brought her enthusiasm for dance to France and provided
financial support. [Catherine's glittering
entertainments](/wiki/Catherine_de%27_Medici%27s_court_festivals "Catherine
de' Medici's court festivals") supported the aims of court politics and
usually were organized around mythological themes.[10] The first _ballet de
cour_ was the _Ballet de Polonais._ This Ballet was performed in 1573 on the
occasion of the visit of the Polish Ambassador. It was choreographed by
Balthasar de Beaaujoyeulx and featured an hour-long dance for sixteen women,
each representing a French province. _Ballet Comique de la Reine_ (1581),
which was also choreographed and directed by [Balthasar de
Beaujoyeulx](/wiki/Balthasar_de_Beaujoyeulx "Balthasar de Beaujoyeulx"), was
commissioned by [Louise of Lorraine](/wiki/Louise_of_Lorraine "Louise of
Lorraine"), queen consort of [King Henry III](/wiki/Henry_III_of_France "Henry
III of France"), son of Catherine, to celebrate the marriage of Henry's
favorite the [Duke de Joyeuse](/wiki/Anne_de_Joyeuse "Anne de Joyeuse") to
Marguerite de Lorraine, the sister of Queen Louise. The ballet lasted for more
than five hours and was danced by twenty four dancers: twelve
[naiades](/wiki/Naiad "Naiad") and twelve pages.[11][12]

In the same year, the publication of [Fabritio Caroso](/wiki/Fabritio_Caroso
"Fabritio Caroso")'s _Il Ballarino_ , a technical manual on court dancing,
both performance and social, helped to establish [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy")
as a centre of technical ballet development.[13]

### 17th century – France and Court
Dance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: 17th century – France and Court Dance")]

Main article: [French ballet](/wiki/French_ballet "French ballet")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Ballet_de_la_nuit_1653.jpg/180px-
Ballet_de_la_nuit_1653.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ballet_de_la_nuit_1653.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ballet_de_la_nuit_1653.jpg "Enlarge")

[Louis XIV](/wiki/Louis_XIV "Louis XIV") in [Lully](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Lully
"Jean-Baptiste Lully")'s _[Ballet Royal de la
Nuit](/wiki/Ballet_Royal_de_la_Nuit "Ballet Royal de la Nuit")_ (1653).

Ballet developed as a performance-focused art form in France during the reign
of [Louis XIV](/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France "Louis XIV of France"), who was
passionate about dance.[14] [Pierre Beauchamp](/wiki/Pierre_Beauchamp "Pierre
Beauchamp"), the man who codified the five basic positions of the
[feet](/wiki/Positions_of_the_feet_in_ballet "Positions of the feet in
ballet") in ballet, was the king's personal dance teacher and favorite partner
in _[ballet de cour](/wiki/Ballet_de_cour "Ballet de cour")_ in the 1650s.[15]
In 1661 Louis XIV, who was determined to reverse a decline in dance standards
that began in the 17th century, established the [Académie Royale de
Danse](/wiki/Acad%C3%A9mie_Royale_de_Danse "Académie Royale de Danse").[14]
Beauchamp was appointed _Intendant des ballets du roi_ and in 1680 became the
director of the dance academy, a position he held until 1687.[15]

[Jean-Baptiste Lully](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Lully "Jean-Baptiste Lully"), an
Italian violinist, dancer, choreographer, and composer, who joined the court
of Louis XIV in 1652,[16] played a significant role in establishing the
general direction ballet would follow for the next century. Supported and
admired by King Louis XIV, Lully often cast the king in his ballets. The title
of _Sun King_ for the French monarch, originated in Louis XIV's role in
Lully's _[Ballet de la Nuit](/wiki/Ballet_de_la_Nuit "Ballet de la Nuit")_
(1653). The fourteen-year-old Louis XIV danced five roles in this 12-hour
ballet.[17] This Ballet was lavish and featured a scene where a set piece of a
house was burned down, included witches, werewolves, gypsies, shepherds,
thieves, and the goddesses Venus and Diana. Lully's main contribution to
ballet were his nuanced compositions. His understanding of movement and dance
allowed him to compose specifically for ballet, with musical phrasings that
complemented physical movements.[18] Lully also collaborated with the French
playwright [Molière](/wiki/Moli%C3%A8re "Molière"). Together, they took an
Italian theatre style, the _commedia dell 'arte_, and adapted it into their
work for a French audience, creating the _[comédie-ballet](/wiki/Com%C3%A9die-
ballet "Comédie-ballet")_. Among their greatest productions, with Beauchamp as
the choreographer,[15] was _[Le Bourgeois
Gentilhomme](/wiki/Le_Bourgeois_Gentilhomme "Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme")_
(1670).[19]

In 1669 Louis XIV founded the [Académie
d'Opéra](/wiki/Acad%C3%A9mie_d%27Op%C3%A9ra "Académie d'Opéra") with [Pierre
Perrin](/wiki/Pierre_Perrin "Pierre Perrin") as director.[20] Louix XIV
retired in 1670, largely because of excessive weight gain. Earlier, in 1661 he
had founded a school, the _Adacemie Royale de danse_. Beauchamp was the first
ballet-master of the Opéra and created the dances for the new company's first
production _Pomone_ with music by [Robert Cambert](/wiki/Robert_Cambert
"Robert Cambert").[15] Later, after Perrin went bankrupt, the king
reestablished the Opéra as the Académie royale de Musique and made Lully the
director.[20] Beauchamp was one of the principal choreographers.[15] In this
position Lully, with his librettist [Philippe
Quinault](/wiki/Philippe_Quinault "Philippe Quinault"), created a new genre,
the _tragédie en musique_ , each act of which featured a _divertissement_ that
was a miniature ballet scene.[16] With almost all his important creations
Jean-Baptiste Lully brought together music and drama with Italian and French
dance elements. His work created a legacy which would define the future of
ballet.

### Popularity throughout
Europe[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Popularity throughout Europe")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Daniel_Rabel_-
_The_Royal_Ballet_of_the_Dowager_of_Bilbao%27s_Grand_Ball_-
_WGA18593.jpg/220px-Daniel_Rabel_-
_The_Royal_Ballet_of_the_Dowager_of_Bilbao%27s_Grand_Ball_-
_WGA18593.jpg)](/wiki/File:Daniel_Rabel_-
_The_Royal_Ballet_of_the_Dowager_of_Bilbao%27s_Grand_Ball_-_WGA18593.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Daniel_Rabel_-
_The_Royal_Ballet_of_the_Dowager_of_Bilbao%27s_Grand_Ball_-_WGA18593.jpg
"Enlarge")

The Royal Ballet of the Dowager of [Bilbao](/wiki/Bilbao "Bilbao")'s Grand
Ball, 1626.

France's court was in some ways the leading source of fashionable culture for
many other royal courts in Europe. Styles of entertainment were imitated,
including the royal ballets. Courts in Spain, Portugal, Poland, Germany, and
elsewhere all became audiences and participants in ballets. In addition to
France, Italy became an important influence on the art form, predominantly
[Venice](/wiki/Venice "Venice").

Professional ballet troupes began to organize and tour Europe, performing for
aristocratic audiences. In Poland, King [Władysław IV
Vasa](/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_IV_Vasa "Władysław IV Vasa") (1633–1648)
hosted Italian opera productions, which included ballet performers in some
scenes. The famous European ballet-masters who worked for the Polish court
include [Louis de
Poitiers](/w/index.php?title=Louis_de_Poitiers_\(ballet_master\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Louis de Poitiers \(ballet master\) \(page does not exist\)"), [Charles
Duparc](/w/index.php?title=Charles_Duparc&action=edit&redlink=1 "Charles
Duparc \(page does not exist\)"), [Jean Favier](/wiki/Jean_Favier "Jean
Favier"), [Antoine Pitrot](/wiki/Antoine_Pitrot "Antoine Pitrot"), [Antonio
Sacco](/wiki/Antonio_Sacco "Antonio Sacco") and [Francesco
Caselli](/w/index.php?title=Francesco_Caselli&action=edit&redlink=1 "Francesco
Caselli \(page does not exist\)").[21]

## 18th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 18th century")]

### France and development as an art
form[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: France and development as an art form")]

The 18th century was a period of advance in the technical standards of ballet
and the period when ballet became a serious dramatic art form on par with the
opera. Central to this advance was the seminal work of [Jean-Georges
Noverre](/wiki/Jean-Georges_Noverre "Jean-Georges Noverre"), _Lettres sur la
danse et les ballets_ (1760), which focused on developing the [ballet
d'action](/wiki/Ballet_d%27action "Ballet d'action"), in which the movements
of the dancers are designed to express character and assist in the narrative.
Noverre believed that: ballet should be technical but also move the audience
emotionally, plots need to be unified, the scenery and music need to support
the plot and be unified within the story, and that pantomime needs to be
simple and understandable.[22]

Reforms were made in ballet composition by composers such as [Christoph
Willibald Gluck](/wiki/Christoph_Willibald_Gluck "Christoph Willibald Gluck").
Finally, ballet was divided into three formal techniques _sérieux_ , _demi-
caractère_ and _comique_. Ballet also began to be featured in operas as
interludes called divertissements.

### Outside
France[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Outside France")]

Venice continued to be a centre of dance in Europe, particularly during the
[Venice Carnival](/wiki/Venice_Carnival "Venice Carnival"), when dancers and
visitors from across the continent would travel to the city for a lively
cultural exchange. The city's [Teatro San
Benedetto](/wiki/Teatro_San_Benedetto "Teatro San Benedetto") became a famous
landmark largely due to the ballets performed there. Italian ballet techniques
remained the dominant influence in much of southern and eastern Europe until
Russian techniques supplanted them in the early 20th century.

Ballet performances spread to Eastern Europe during the 18th century, into
areas such as Hungary, where they were held in private theatres at
aristocratic castles. Professional companies were established that performed
throughout Hungary and also toured abroad. The Budapest National Theatre
increasingly serving a role as a home for the dancers.[23]

Some of the leading dancers of the time who performed throughout Europe were
[Louis Dupré](/wiki/Louis_Dupr%C3%A9_\(dancer\) "Louis Dupré \(dancer\)"),
[Charles Le Picque](/w/index.php?title=Charles_Le_Picque&action=edit&redlink=1
"Charles Le Picque \(page does not exist\)") with [Anna
Binetti](/w/index.php?title=Anna_Binetti&action=edit&redlink=1 "Anna Binetti
\(page does not exist\)"), [Gaetano Vestris](/wiki/Gaetano_Vestris "Gaetano
Vestris"), and [Jean-Georges Noverre](/wiki/Jean-Georges_Noverre "Jean-Georges
Noverre").[21]

## 19th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: 19th century")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Ballet_Carneval_von_Venedig_Berlin_1827.jpg/180px-
Ballet_Carneval_von_Venedig_Berlin_1827.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ballet_Carneval_von_Venedig_Berlin_1827.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ballet_Carneval_von_Venedig_Berlin_1827.jpg "Enlarge")

Polish ballet performers at the 1827 [Venice Carnival](/wiki/Venice_Carnival
"Venice Carnival"). The dancer on the left is performing "en travestie" as a
woman taking the man's role.

The [ballerina](/wiki/Ballerina "Ballerina") became the most popular dance
performer in Europe in the first half of the 19th century, gradually turning
the spotlight away from the male dancer. In many performances, ballet heroes
were played by a woman, like the Principal Boy in [pantomime](/wiki/Pantomime
"Pantomime").[24]

The professionalism of ballet companies became a focus for a new generation of
ballet masters and dancers. Vienna was an important source of influential
ballet coaches. The first ballet master of Hungary's National Theatre and
Royal Opera was the [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna")-born [Frigyes
Campilli](/w/index.php?title=Frigyes_Campilli&action=edit&redlink=1 "Frigyes
Campilli \(page does not exist\)"), who worked in [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest
"Budapest") for 40 years.[25]

Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(April 2010)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

The 19th century was a period of great social change, which was reflected in
ballet by a shift away from the aristocratic sensibilities that had dominated
earlier periods through [romantic ballet](/wiki/Romantic_ballet "Romantic
ballet"). Ballerinas such as [Geneviève
Gosselin](/wiki/Genevi%C3%A8ve_Gosselin "Geneviève Gosselin"), [Marie
Taglioni](/wiki/Marie_Taglioni "Marie Taglioni") and [Fanny
Elssler](/wiki/Fanny_Elssler "Fanny Elssler") experimented with new techniques
such as [pointework](/wiki/Pointework "Pointework") that gave the ballerina
prominence as the ideal stage figure. Taglioni was known as the "Christian
Dancer," as her image was light and pure (associated with her role as the
sylph in La Sylphide). She was trained primarily by her father, Filipo
Taglioni. In 1834, Fanny Elssler arrived at the Paris Opera and became known
as the "Pagan Dancer," because of the fiery qualities of the _Cachucha_ dance
that made her famous. Professional librettists began crafting the stories in
ballets. Teachers like [Carlo Blasis](/wiki/Carlo_Blasis "Carlo Blasis")
codified ballet technique in the basic form that is still used today. The
ballet boxed toe shoe was invented to support pointe work.

### Romantic
movement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Romantic movement")]

Main article: [Romantic ballet](/wiki/Romantic_ballet "Romantic ballet")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Marie-taglioni-in-
zephire.jpg/180px-Marie-taglioni-in-zephire.jpg)](/wiki/File:Marie-taglioni-
in-zephire.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Marie-taglioni-in-zephire.jpg "Enlarge")

[Marie Taglioni](/wiki/Marie_Taglioni "Marie Taglioni") as Flore in [Charles
Didelot](/wiki/Charles_Didelot "Charles Didelot")'s ballet _[Flore et
Zéphire](/wiki/Flore_et_Z%C3%A9phire "Flore et Zéphire")_ (ca. 1831). She was
a pioneer of [pointework](/wiki/En_pointe "En pointe").

The [Romantic movement](/wiki/Romantic_movement "Romantic movement") in art,
literature, and theatre was a reaction against formal constraints and the
mechanics of industrialization.[22] The [zeitgeist](/wiki/Zeitgeist
"Zeitgeist") led choreographers to compose romantic ballets that appeared
light, airy and free that would act as a contrast to the spread of
reductionist science through many aspects of daily life that had, in the words
of Poe, "driven the hamadryad from the woods". These "unreal" ballets
portrayed women as fragile unearthly beings, ethereal creatures who could be
lifted effortlessly and almost seemed to float in the air. Ballerinas began to
wear costumes with pastel, flowing skirts that bared the shins. The stories
revolved around uncanny, folkloric spirits. An example of one such romantic
ballet is _[La Sylphide](/wiki/La_Sylphide "La Sylphide")_ , one of the oldest
romantic ballets still performed today.

One strain of the Romantic movement was a new exploration of folklore and
traditional ethnic culture. This influence was seen in the emergence of
European folk dance and western portrayals of African, Asian, and Middle East
peoples on European stages. In ballets from this period, non-European
characters were often created as villains or as silly divertisements to fit
the [orientalist](/wiki/Orientalism "Orientalism") western understanding of
the world.[26] The [National Opera of Ukraine](/wiki/National_Opera_of_Ukraine
"National Opera of Ukraine"), a performing arts theatre with a resident opera
company, was established in [Kiev](/wiki/Kiev "Kiev") in 1867. It also
included a small resident troupe of ballet dancers, who would perform mainly
folk-style dancing during opera productions. By 1893, this grew to a troupe
large enough to stage large ballets. Folk dancing and ballets with Ukrainian
stories were among the early productions.[27]

Many leading European professional ballet companies that survive today were
established at new theatres in Europe's capital cities during the mid- to
late- 19th century, including the [Kiev Ballet](/wiki/Kiev_Ballet "Kiev
Ballet"), the [Hungarian National Ballet](/wiki/Hungarian_National_Ballet
"Hungarian National Ballet"), the [National Theatre Ballet
(Prague)](/wiki/National_Theatre_Ballet_\(Prague\) "National Theatre Ballet
\(Prague\)") and the [Vienna State Ballet](/wiki/Vienna_State_Ballet "Vienna
State Ballet") (formerly the [Vienna State Opera](/wiki/Vienna_State_Opera
"Vienna State Opera") Ballet). These theatres usually combined large opera,
drama and ballet companies under the same roof. Composers, dramatists, and
choreographers were then able to create works that took advantage of the
ability to collaborate among these performance troupes.

### Russia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Russia")]

Main article: [Russian ballet](/wiki/Russian_ballet "Russian ballet")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Swanlakemordkin.jpg/180px-
Swanlakemordkin.jpg)](/wiki/File:Swanlakemordkin.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Swanlakemordkin.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mikhail Mordkin](/wiki/Mikhail_Mordkin "Mikhail Mordkin") as Prince Siegfried
and [Adelaide Giuri](/w/index.php?title=Adelaide_Giuri&action=edit&redlink=1
"Adelaide Giuri \(page does not exist\)") as Odette with students as the
little swans in the Moscow Imperial Bolshoi Theatre's production of the
Petipa/Ivanov/Tchaikovsky _[Swan Lake](/wiki/Swan_Lake "Swan Lake")_. 1901

While France was instrumental in early ballet, other countries and cultures
soon adopted the art form, most notably Russia. Russia has a recognized
tradition of ballet, and Russian ballet has had great importance in its
country throughout history. After 1850, ballet began to wane in Paris, but it
flourished in [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark") and [Russia](/wiki/Russia
"Russia") thanks to masters such as [August
Bournonville](/wiki/August_Bournonville "August Bournonville"), [Jules
Perrot](/wiki/Jules_Perrot "Jules Perrot"), [Arthur Saint-
Léon](/wiki/Arthur_Saint-L%C3%A9on "Arthur Saint-Léon"), [Enrico
Cecchetti](/wiki/Enrico_Cecchetti "Enrico Cecchetti") and [Marius
Petipa](/wiki/Marius_Petipa "Marius Petipa"). In the late nineteenth century,
[orientalism](/wiki/Orientalism "Orientalism") was in vogue. Colonialism
brought awareness of Asian and African cultures, but distorted with
disinformation and fantasy. The East was often perceived as a faraway place
where anything was possible, provided it was lavish, exotic and decadent.
Petipa appealed to popular taste with _[The Pharaoh's
Daughter](/wiki/The_Pharaoh%27s_Daughter "The Pharaoh's Daughter")_ (1862),
and later _[The Talisman](/wiki/The_Talisman_\(ballet\) "The Talisman
\(ballet\)")_ (1889), and _[La Bayadère](/wiki/La_Bayad%C3%A8re "La
Bayadère")_ (1877). Petipa is best remembered for his collaborations with
[Tchaikovsky](/wiki/Tchaikovsky "Tchaikovsky"). He used his music for his
choreography of _[The Nutcracker](/wiki/The_Nutcracker "The Nutcracker")_
(1892, though this is open to some debate among historians), _[The Sleeping
Beauty](/wiki/The_Sleeping_Beauty_Ballet "The Sleeping Beauty Ballet")_
(1890), and the definitive revival of _[Swan Lake](/wiki/Swan_Lake "Swan
Lake")_ (1895, with [Lev Ivanov](/wiki/Lev_Ivanov "Lev Ivanov")). These works
were all drawn from European folklore.

The female dancers' classical [tutu](/wiki/Ballet_tutu "Ballet tutu") as it is
recognized today began to appear at this time. It consisted of a short, stiff
skirt supported by layers of crinoline or tulle that revealed the acrobatic
legwork, combined with a wide gusset that served to preserve modesty.

###
Argentina[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Argentina")]

Ballet companies from Europe began lucrative tours of theatres in North,
Central and South America during the mid-19th century. The prestigious [Colon
Theater](/wiki/Colon_Theater "Colon Theater") in Buenos Aires, Argentina had
hosted foreign ballet artists on its stage, with touring companies from Europe
presenting full ballets as early as 1867.[28] By the 1880s, the Colon Theater
had its own professional ballet company. It would still be several decades
before most countries outside of Europe could claim their own professional
ballet companies, however.

## 20th century and
modernism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: 20th century and modernism")]

### Russia and the Ballets
Russes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Russia and the Ballets Russes")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Pavlova_Anna_as_a_bacchante_in_The_Seasons.jpg/180px-
Pavlova_Anna_as_a_bacchante_in_The_Seasons.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pavlova_Anna_as_a_bacchante_in_The_Seasons.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pavlova_Anna_as_a_bacchante_in_The_Seasons.jpg "Enlarge")

[Anna Pavlova](/wiki/Anna_Pavlova "Anna Pavlova") as a
[bacchante](/wiki/Bacchante "Bacchante") in _[Bacchanale](/wiki/Bacchanale
"Bacchanale")_ by [Mikhail Mordkin](/wiki/Mikhail_Mordkin "Mikhail Mordkin").

[Sergei Diaghilev](/wiki/Sergei_Diaghilev "Sergei Diaghilev") brought ballet
full-circle back to Paris when he opened his company, [Ballets
Russes](/wiki/Ballets_Russes "Ballets Russes"). It was made up of dancers from
the Russian exile community in Paris after the Revolution.

Diaghilev and composer [Igor Stravinsky](/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky "Igor
Stravinsky") merged their talents to bring Russian folklore to life in _[The
Firebird](/wiki/The_Firebird "The Firebird")_ and _[Petrushka](/wiki/Petrushka
"Petrushka")_ choreographed by Fokine. Diaghilev's next choreographic
commissions went to Nijinsky. His First ballet was _L 'apres-midi d'un Faune_
(Afternoon of a Faun) to music by Debussy. It was notable for its two
dimensional shapes and lack of ballet technique. It caused controversy by
depicting the faun rubbing the scarf of one of the maidens on himself, in
simulated masturbation. The most controversial work of the Ballets Russes
however, was _[The Rite of Spring](/wiki/The_Rite_of_Spring "The Rite of
Spring")_ , choreographed by Nijinsky with music by Stravinsky. The ballet's
modern music, pigeon toed stomping and theme of human sacrifice shocked
audiences so much they rioted.

After the “golden age” of Petipa, [Michel Fokine](/wiki/Michel_Fokine "Michel
Fokine") began his career in St. Petersburg but moved to Paris and worked with
Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Vaslav_Nijinsky_in_Le_spectre_de_la_rose_1911_Royal_Opera_House.jpg/200px-
Vaslav_Nijinsky_in_Le_spectre_de_la_rose_1911_Royal_Opera_House.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vaslav_Nijinsky_in_Le_spectre_de_la_rose_1911_Royal_Opera_House.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vaslav_Nijinsky_in_Le_spectre_de_la_rose_1911_Royal_Opera_House.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Vaslav Nijinsky](/wiki/Vaslav_Nijinsky "Vaslav Nijinsky") in _[The Spectre of
the Rose](/wiki/The_Spectre_of_the_Rose "The Spectre of the Rose")_ , 1911.

Russian ballet continued development under Soviet rule. There was little
talent left in the country after the Revolution, but it was enough to seed a
new generation. After stagnation in the 1920s, by the mid-1930s that new
generation of dancers and choreographers appeared on the scene. The technical
perfection and precision of dance was promoted (and demanded) by [Agrippina
Vaganova](/wiki/Agrippina_Vaganova "Agrippina Vaganova"), who had been taught
by Petipa and Cecchetti and headed the [Vaganova Ballet
Academy](/wiki/Vaganova_Ballet_Academy "Vaganova Ballet Academy"), the school
to prepare dancers for the Kirov Ballet in St. Petersburg/Leningrad.

Ballet was popular with the public. Both the Moscow-based Bolshoi and the St.
Petersburg (then Leningrad)-based Kirov ballet companies were active.
Ideological pressure forced the creation of many [socialist
realist](/wiki/Socialist_realist "Socialist realist") pieces, most of which
made little impression on the public and were removed from the repertoire of
both companies later.

Some pieces of that era, however, were remarkable. The _[Romeo and
Juliet](/wiki/Romeo_and_Juliet "Romeo and Juliet")_ by
[Prokofiev](/wiki/Prokofiev "Prokofiev") and [Lavrovsky](/wiki/Lavrovsky
"Lavrovsky") is a masterpiece. The _[Flames of Paris](/wiki/Flames_of_Paris
"Flames of Paris")_ , while it shows all the faults of socialist realist art,
pioneered the active use of the corps de ballet in the performance and
required stunning virtuosity. The [ballet
version](/wiki/The_Fountain_of_Bakhchisarai_\(ballet\) "The Fountain of
Bakhchisarai \(ballet\)") of the [Pushkin](/wiki/Pushkin "Pushkin") poem,
_[The Fountain of Bakhchisarai](/wiki/The_Fountain_of_Bakhchisarai "The
Fountain of Bakhchisarai")_ with music from [Boris
Asafiev](/wiki/Boris_Asafiev "Boris Asafiev") and choreography by [Rostislav
Zakharov](/wiki/Rostislav_Zakharov "Rostislav Zakharov") was also a hit.

The well-known ballet _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(Prokofiev\) "Cinderella
\(Prokofiev\)")_ , for which Prokofiev provided the music, is also the product
of the Soviet ballet. During the Soviet era, these pieces were mostly unknown
outside the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") and later
outside of the [Eastern Bloc](/wiki/Eastern_Bloc "Eastern Bloc"). However,
after the collapse of the Soviet Union they received more recognition.

The 1999 North American premiere of _[The Fountain of
Bakhchisarai](/wiki/The_Fountain_of_Bakhchisarai_\(ballet\) "The Fountain of
Bakhchisarai \(ballet\)")_ by the Kirov Ballet in New York was an outstanding
success, for example. The Soviet era of the Russian Ballet put a lot of
emphasis on technique, virtuosity and strength. It demanded strength usually
above the norm of contemporary Western dancers. When watching restored old
footage, one can only marvel at the talent of their prima ballerinas such as
[Galina Ulanova](/wiki/Galina_Ulanova "Galina Ulanova"), [Natalya
Dudinskaya](/wiki/Natalya_Dudinskaya "Natalya Dudinskaya") and [Maya
Plisetskaya](/wiki/Maya_Plisetskaya "Maya Plisetskaya") and choreographers
such as [Pyotr Gusev](/wiki/Pyotr_Gusev "Pyotr Gusev").

Russian companies, particularly after World War II engaged in multiple tours
all over the world that revitalized ballet in the West.

_[Maiden Tower](/wiki/Maiden_Tower_\(ballet\) "Maiden Tower \(ballet\)")_[29]
written by [Afrasiyab Badalbeyli](/wiki/Afrasiyab_Badalbeyli "Afrasiyab
Badalbeyli") is the first ballet in the [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim")
East.[30][31][29]

### United States of
America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: United States of America")]

Following the move of the Ballets Russes to France, ballet began to have a
broader influence, particularly in the United States of America.

From Paris, after disagreements with Diaghilev, Fokine went to Sweden and then
the USA and settled in New York. Diaghilev believed that traditional ballet
offered little more than prettiness and athletic display. For Fokine that was
not enough. In addition to technical virtuosity he demanded drama, expression
and historical authenticity. The choreographer must research the period and
cultural context of the setting and reject the traditional tutu in favour of
accurate period costuming.

Fokine choreographed _[Sheherazade](/wiki/Scheherazade_\(Rimsky-Korsakov\)
"Scheherazade \(Rimsky-Korsakov\)")_ and _[Cleopatra](/wiki/Cleopatra_ballet
"Cleopatra ballet")_. He also reworked _Petrouchka_ and _The Firebird_. One of
his most famous works was _[The Dying Swan](/wiki/The_Dying_Swan "The Dying
Swan")_ , performed by [Anna Pavlova](/wiki/Anna_Pavlova "Anna Pavlova").
Beyond her talents as a ballerina, Pavlova had the theatrical gifts to fulfill
Fokine's vision of ballet as drama. Legend has it that Pavlova identified so
much with the swan role that she requested her swan costume from her deathbed.

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/La_Mort_du_Cygne_1_Anna_Pavlova_2_Yvette_Chauvire_3_Natalia_Makarova.mpg.ogv/192px
--
La_Mort_du_Cygne_1_Anna_Pavlova_2_Yvette_Chauvire_3_Natalia_Makarova.mpg.ogv.jpg)

[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/3/3c/La_Mort_du_Cygne_1_Anna_Pavlova_2_Yvette_Chauvire_3_Natalia_Makarova.mpg.ogv/La_Mort_du_Cygne_1_Anna_Pavlova_2_Yvette_Chauvire_3_Natalia_Makarova.mpg.ogv.160p.webm)

[](/wiki/File:La_Mort_du_Cygne_1_Anna_Pavlova_2_Yvette_Chauvire_3_Natalia_Makarova.mpg.ogv
"Enlarge")

_[The Dying Swan](/wiki/The_Dying_Swan "The Dying Swan")_ choreographed by
[Fokine](/wiki/Fokine "Fokine"), performed by three soloists (shown in order):
1. [Anna Pavlova](/wiki/Anna_Pavlova "Anna Pavlova") (7 seconds) 2. [Yvette
Chauvire](/wiki/Yvette_Chauvire "Yvette Chauvire") (10 seconds) 3. [Natalia
Makarova](/wiki/Natalia_Makarova "Natalia Makarova") (14 seconds).

[George Balanchine](/wiki/George_Balanchine "George Balanchine") developed
state-of-the-art technique in America by opening a school in Chicago and more
importantly, in New York. He adapted ballet to the new media, movies and
television.[32] A prolific worker, Balanchine rechoreographed classics such as
_Swan Lake_ and _Sleeping Beauty_ as well as creating new ballets. He produced
original interpretations of the dramas of [William
Shakespeare](/wiki/William_Shakespeare "William Shakespeare") such as _[Romeo
and Juliet](/wiki/Romeo_and_Juliet "Romeo and Juliet")_ and _[A Midsummer
Night's Dream](/wiki/A_Midsummer_Night%27s_Dream "A Midsummer Night's
Dream")_, and also of Franz Léhar's _[The Merry Widow](/wiki/The_Merry_Widow
"The Merry Widow")_.

In 1967, Balanchine's _[Jewels](/wiki/Jewels_\(ballet\) "Jewels \(ballet\)")_
broke with the narrative tradition and dramatized a theme rather than a plot.
This focus fits with the state-sponsored funding sources in the United States
which sought to encourage "liberty and freethinking" in contrast to narrative-
driven dance, which was seen as to be connected too closely with socialism,
especially [Soviet communism](/wiki/State_ideology_of_the_Soviet_Union "State
ideology of the Soviet Union").[33] Today, partly thanks to Balanchine, ballet
is one of the most well-preserved dances in the world.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Barbara Karinska was a Russian emigree and a skilled seamstress who
collaborated with Balanchine to elevate the art of costume design from a
secondary role to an integral part of a ballet performance. She introduced the
[bias cut](/wiki/Bias_cut "Bias cut") and a simplified classic tutu that
allowed the dancer more freedom of movement. With meticulous attention to
detail, she decorated her tutus with beadwork, embroidery, crochet and
appliqué.

## Neoclassical
ballet[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Neoclassical ballet")]

Main article: [Neoclassical ballet](/wiki/Neoclassical_ballet "Neoclassical
ballet")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Ballets_Russes_-
_Apollo_musag%C3%A8te.jpg/200px-Ballets_Russes_-
_Apollo_musag%C3%A8te.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ballets_Russes_-
_Apollo_musag%C3%A8te.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ballets_Russes_-_Apollo_musag%C3%A8te.jpg "Enlarge")

[Ballets Russes](/wiki/Ballets_Russes "Ballets Russes") with
_[Apollo](/wiki/Apollo_\(ballet\) "Apollo \(ballet\)")_ (1928) choreographed
by [George Balanchine](/wiki/George_Balanchine "George Balanchine"). Dancers
are [Alexandrova
Danilova](/w/index.php?title=Alexandrova_Danilova&action=edit&redlink=1
"Alexandrova Danilova \(page does not exist\)") and [Serge
Lifar](/wiki/Serge_Lifar "Serge Lifar").

[George Balanchine](/wiki/George_Balanchine "George Balanchine") is often
considered to have been the first pioneer of what is now known as
[neoclassical ballet](/wiki/Neoclassical_ballet "Neoclassical ballet"), a
style of dance between classical ballet and today's contemporary ballet. Tim
Scholl, author of _From Petipa to Balanchine_ , considers Balanchine's
_[Apollo](/wiki/Apollo_\(ballet\) "Apollo \(ballet\)")_ (1928) to be the first
neoclassical ballet. It represented a return to form in response to [Serge
Diaghilev](/wiki/Serge_Diaghilev "Serge Diaghilev")'s abstract ballets.
_Apollo_ and other works are still performed today, predominantly by the [New
York City Ballet](/wiki/New_York_City_Ballet "New York City Ballet"). However,
other companies are able to pay a fee for performance rights to George
Balanchine's works.

[Frederick Ashton](/wiki/Frederick_Ashton "Frederick Ashton") is another
prominent choreographer associated with the neoclassical style. Three of his
works have become standard pieces in the international repertoire:
_[Sylvia](/wiki/Sylvia_\(ballet\) "Sylvia \(ballet\)")_ (1952), _[Romeo and
Juliet](/wiki/Romeo_and_Juliet_\(ballet\) "Romeo and Juliet \(ballet\)")_
(1956), and _[Ondine](/wiki/Ondine_\(ballet\) "Ondine \(ballet\)")_ (1958),
the last of which was created as a vehicle to showcase [Margot
Fonteyn](/wiki/Margot_Fonteyn "Margot Fonteyn").

##
Contemporary[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Contemporary")]

Main article: [Contemporary ballet](/wiki/Contemporary_ballet "Contemporary
ballet")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Allah_Garibou.jpg/200px-
Allah_Garibou.jpg)](/wiki/File:Allah_Garibou.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Allah_Garibou.jpg "Enlarge")

A 2010 performance of [Irène Tassembédo](/wiki/Ir%C3%A8ne_Tassemb%C3%A9do
"Irène Tassembédo")'s [contemporary ballet](/wiki/Contemporary_ballet
"Contemporary ballet") piece [Allah
Garibou](/w/index.php?title=Allah_Garibou&action=edit&redlink=1 "Allah Garibou
\(page does not exist\)").

One dancer who trained with Balanchine and absorbed much of this neo-classical
style was [Mikhail Baryshnikov](/wiki/Mikhail_Baryshnikov "Mikhail
Baryshnikov"). Following Baryshnikov's appointment as artistic director of
[American Ballet Theatre](/wiki/American_Ballet_Theatre "American Ballet
Theatre") in 1980, he worked with various modern choreographers, most notably
[Twyla Tharp](/wiki/Twyla_Tharp "Twyla Tharp"). Tharp choreographed _Push
Comes To Shove_ for ABT and Baryshnikov in 1976; in 1986 she created _In The
Upper Room_ for her own company. Both these pieces were considered innovative
for their use of distinctly modern movements melded with the use of pointe
shoes and classically trained dancers—for their use of contemporary ballet.

Tharp also worked with the [Joffrey Ballet](/wiki/Joffrey_Ballet "Joffrey
Ballet") company, founded in 1957 by [Robert Joffrey](/wiki/Robert_Joffrey
"Robert Joffrey"). She choreographed _[Deuce Coupe](/wiki/Deuce_Coupe "Deuce
Coupe")_ for them in 1973, using pop music and a blend of modern and ballet
techniques. The Joffrey Ballet continued to perform numerous contemporary
pieces, many choreographed by co-founder [Gerald Arpino](/wiki/Gerald_Arpino
"Gerald Arpino").

Today there are many contemporary ballet companies and choreographers. These
include [Madrid Ballet](/wiki/Madrid_Ballet "Madrid Ballet"); [Royal Ballet of
Flanders](/wiki/Royal_Ballet_of_Flanders "Royal Ballet of Flanders"); [Alonzo
King](/wiki/Alonzo_King "Alonzo King") and his company, [Alonzo King LINES
Ballet](/wiki/Alonzo_King_LINES_Ballet "Alonzo King LINES Ballet"); Nacho
Duato and [Compañia Nacional de Danza](/wiki/Compa%C3%B1ia_Nacional_de_Danza
"Compañia Nacional de Danza"); William Forsythe, who has worked extensively
with the [Frankfurt
Ballet](/w/index.php?title=Frankfurt_Ballet&action=edit&redlink=1 "Frankfurt
Ballet \(page does not exist\)") and today runs [The Forsythe
Company](/wiki/The_Forsythe_Company "The Forsythe Company"); and [Jiří
Kylián](/wiki/Ji%C5%99%C3%AD_Kyli%C3%A1n "Jiří Kylián"), formerly the artistic
director of the [Nederlands Dans Theater](/wiki/Nederlands_Dans_Theater
"Nederlands Dans Theater"). Traditionally "classical" companies, such as the
[Kirov Ballet](/wiki/Kirov_Ballet "Kirov Ballet") and the [Paris Opera
Ballet](/wiki/Paris_Opera_Ballet "Paris Opera Ballet"), also regularly perform
contemporary works.

## Development of ballet
method[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_ballet&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Development of ballet method")]

Main article: [Ballet training](/wiki/Ballet_training "Ballet training")

Several well-known ballet methods are named after their originators. For
example, two prevailing systems from Russia are known as the [Vaganova
method](/wiki/Vaganova_method "Vaganova method") after [Agrippina
Vaganova](/wiki/Agrippina_Vaganova "Agrippina Vaganova"), and the Legat
Method, after [Nikolai Legat](/wiki/Nikolai_Legat "Nikolai Legat"). The
[Cecchetti method](/wiki/Cecchetti_method "Cecchetti method") was invented by
Italian dancer [Enrico Cecchetti](/wiki/Enrico_Cecchetti "Enrico Cecchetti")
(1850–1928), and the Bournonville method, which was invented by [August
Bournonville](/wiki/August_Bournonville "August Bournonville") (1805–1879), is
employed chiefly in Bournonville's own country of Denmark.

qa.question: dance created for the entertainment of the aristocracy is called
